1B-CS-01.description: Describe how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a system.

1B-CS-02.description: Model how computer hardware and software work together as a system to accomplish tasks.

1B-CS-03.description: Determine potential solutions to solve simple hardware and software problems using common troubleshooting strategies.

2-CS-01.description: Recommend improvements to the design of computing devices, based on an analysis of how users interact with the devices.

2-CS-02.description: Design projects that combine hardware and software components to collect and exchange data.

2-CS-03.description: Systematically identify and fix problems with computing devices and their components.

3A-CS-01.description: Explain how abstractions hide the underlying implementation details of computing systems embedded in everyday objects.

3A-CS-02.description: Compare levels of abstraction and interactions between application software, system software, and hardware layers

3A-CS-03.description: Develop guidelines that convey systematic troubleshooting strategies that others can use to identify and fix errors

3B-CS-01.description: Categorize the roles of operating system software.

3B-CS-02.description: Illustrate ways computing systems implement logic, input, and output through hardware components

1B-NI-04.description: Model how information is broken down into smaller pieces, transmitted as packets through multiple devices over networks and the Internet, and reassembled at the destination.

1B-NI-05.description: Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems and how personal information can be protected.

2-NI-04.description: Model the role of protocols in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.

2-NI-05.description: Explain how physical and digital security measures protect electronic information.

2-NI-06.description: Apply multiple methods of encryption to model the secure transmission of information

3A-NI-04.description: Evaluate the scalability and reliability of networks, by describing the relationship between routers, switches, servers, topology, and addressing.

3A-NI-05.description: Give examples to illustrate how sensitive data can be affected by malware and other attacks

3A-NI-06.description: Recommend security measures to address various scenarios based on factors such as efficiency, feasibility, and ethical impacts.

3A-NI-07.description: Compare various security measures, considering tradeoffs between the usability and security of a computing system

3A-NI-08.description: Explain tradeoffs when selecting and implementing cybersecurity recommendations.

3B-NI-03.description: Describe the issues that impact network functionality (e.g., bandwidth, load, delay, topology).

3B-NI-04.description: Compare ways software developers protect devices and information from unauthorized access.

3B-NI-05.description: Use data analysis tools and techniques to identify patterns in data representing complex systems

3B-NI-06.description: Select data collection tools and techniques to generate data sets that support a claim or communicate information.

3B-NI-07.description: Evaluate the ability of models and simulations to test and support the refinement of hypotheses.

1B-DA-06.description: Organize and present collected data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim.

1B-DA-07.description: Use data to highlight or propose cause-and-effect relationships, predict outcomes, or communicate an idea.

2-DA-07.description: Represent data using multiple encoding schemes.

2-DA-08.description: Collect data using computational tools and transform the data to make it more useful and reliable.

2-DA-09.description: Refine computational models based on the data they have generated.

3A-DA-09.description: Translate between different bit representations of real-world phenomena, such as characters, numbers, and images.

3A-DA-10.description: Evaluate the tradeoffs in how data elements are organized and where data is stored.

3A-DA-11.description: Create interactive data visualizations using software tools to help others better understand real-world phenomena.

3A-DA-12.description: Create computational models that represent the relationships among different elements of data collected from a phenomenon or process.

1B-AP-08.description: Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most appropriate.

1B-AP-09.description: Create programs that use variables to store and modify data.

1B-AP-10.description: Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, and conditionals.

1B-AP-11.description: Decompose (break down) problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.

1B-AP-12.description: Modify, remix, or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work, to develop something new or add more advanced features.

1B-AP-13.description: Use an iterative process to plan the development of a program by including others' perspectives and considering user preferences.

1B-AP-14.description: Observe intellectual property rights and give appropriate attribution when creating or remixing programs.

1B-AP-15.description: Test and debug (identify and fix errors) a program or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.

1B-AP-16.description: Take on varying roles, with teacher guidance, when collaborating with peers during the design, implementation, and review stages of program development.

1B-AP-17.description: Describe choices made during program development using code comments, presentations, and demonstrations.

2-AP-10.description: Use flowcharts and/or pseudocode to address complex problems as algorithms

2-AP-11.description: Create clearly named variables that represent different data types and perform operations on their values.

2-AP-12.description: Design and iteratively develop programs that combine control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals

2-AP-13.description: Decompose problems and subproblems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and review of programs

2-AP-14.description: Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.

2-AP-15.description: Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution that meets user needs.

2-AP-16.description: Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs, and give attribution.

2-AP-17.description: Systematically test and refine programs using a range of test cases

2-AP-18.description: Distribute tasks and maintain a project timeline when collaboratively developing computational artifacts.

2-AP-19.description: Document programs in order to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.

3A-AP-13.description: Create prototypes that use algorithms to solve computational problems by leveraging prior student knowledge and personal interests.

3A-AP-14.description: Use lists to simplify solutions, generalizing computational problems instead of repeatedly using simple variables

3A-AP-15.description: Justify the selection of specific control structures when tradeoffs involve implementation, readability, and program performance, and explain the benefits and drawbacks of choices made.

3A-AP-16.description: Design and iteratively develop computational artifacts for practical intent, personal expression, or to address a societal issue by using events to initiate instructions.

3A-AP-17.description: Decompose problems into smaller components through systematic analysis, using constructs such as procedures, modules, and/or objects.

3A-AP-18.description: Create artifacts by using procedures within a program, combinations of data and procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.

3A-AP-19.description: Systematically design and develop programs for broad audiences by incorporating feedback from users

3A-AP-20.description: Evaluate licenses that limit or restrict use of computational artifacts when using resources such as libraries

3A-AP-21.description: Evaluate and refine computational artifacts to make them more usable and accessible.

3A-AP-22.description: Design and develop computational artifacts working in team roles using collaborative tools

3A-AP-23.description: Document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations, and/or demonstrations in the development of complex programs.

3B-AP-08.description: Describe how artificial intelligence drives many software and physical systems.

3B-AP-09.description: Implement an artificial intelligence algorithm to play a game against a human opponent or solve a problem.

3B-AP-10.description: Use and adapt classic algorithms to solve computational problems.

3B-AP-11.description: Evaluate algorithms in terms of their efficiency, correctness, and clarity.

3B-AP-12.description: Compare and contrast fundamental data structures and their uses.

3B-AP-13.description: Illustrate the flow of execution of a recursive algorithm

3B-AP-14.description: Construct solutions to problems using student-created components, such as procedures, modules and/or objects.

3B-AP-15.description: Analyze a large-scale computational problem and identify generalizable patterns that can be applied to a solution

3B-AP-16.description: Demonstrate code reuse by creating programming solutions using libraries and APIs.

3B-AP-17.description: Plan and develop programs for broad audiences using a software life cycle process.

3B-AP-18.description: Explain security issues that might lead to compromised computer programs

3B-AP-19.description: Develop programs for multiple computing platforms.

3B-AP-20.description: Use version control systems, integrated development environments (IDEs), and collaborative tools and practices (code documentation) in a group software project.

3B-AP-21.description: Develop and use a series of test cases to verify that a program performs according to its design specifications.

3B-AP-22.description: Modify an existing program to add additional functionality and discuss intended and unintended implications (e.g., breaking other functionality).

3B-AP-23.description: Evaluate key qualities of a program through a process such as a code review

3B-AP-24.description: Compare multiple programming languages and discuss how their features make them suitable for solving different types of problems.

1B-IC-18.description: Discuss computing technologies that have changed the world, and express how those technologies influence, and are influenced by, cultural practices.

1B-IC-19.description: Brainstorm ways to improve the accessibility and usability of technology products for the diverse needs and wants of users.

1B-IC-20.description: Seek diverse perspectives for the purpose of improving computational artifacts.

1B-IC-21.description: Use public domain or creative commons media, and refrain from copying or using material created by others without permission.

2-IC-20.description: Compare tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that affect people's everyday activities and career options.

2-IC-21.description: Discuss issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies

2-IC-22.description: Collaborate with many contributors through strategies such as crowdsourcing or surveys when creating a computational artifact.

2-IC-23.description: Describe tradeoffs between allowing information to be public and keeping information private and secure.

3A-IC-24.description: Evaluate the ways computing impacts personal, ethical, social, economic, and cultural practices

3A-IC-25.description: Test and refine computational artifacts to reduce bias and equity deficits.

3A-IC-26.description: Demonstrate ways a given algorithm applies to problems across disciplines.

3A-IC-27.description: Use tools and methods for collaboration on a project to increase connectivity of people in different cultures and career fields

3A-IC-28.description: Explain the beneficial and harmful effects that intellectual property laws can have on innovation.

3A-IC-29.description: Explain the privacy concerns related to the collection and generation of data through automated processes that may not be evident to users.

3A-IC-30.description: Evaluate the social and economic implications of privacy in the context of safety, law, or ethics.

3B-IC-25.description: Evaluate computational artifacts to maximize their beneficial effects and minimize harmful effects on society.

3B-IC-26.description: Evaluate the impact of equity, access, and influence on the distribution of computing resources in a global society.

3B-IC-27.description: Predict how computational innovations that have revolutionized aspects of our culture might evolve.

3B-IC-28.description: Debate laws and regulations that impact the development and use of software.
